soil_crop_relationships.subject: sandy soils
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Sandy soils retain less moisture and nutrients

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Fertile Soils
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Weeds such as Katabuteme, Sekoteka, Kafumbe, and Lusenke indicate fertile soils

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Poor Soils
soil_crop_relationships.object: black jack, couch grass, Kakuuku, Eteete, and Muwugulaomunene
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: black jack, couch grass, Kakuuku, Eteete, and Muwugulaomunene grow on poor soils

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Good soils
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: crops such as banana do well on good soils

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Poor soils
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: mango can grow on poor soils

management_practices.effect: increase moisture and nutrient retention
management_practices.evidence: Sandy soils retain less moisture and nutrients, and therefore, can be managed by providing water, organic matter, and fertilizers.

management_practices.effect: Insufficient to replenish mined nutrients
management_practices.evidence: NARO and FAO (1999) estimate that smallholderfarmers inUgandaapplyanaverage of1kgofNPK/ha.

management_practices.effect: Restoration of mined nutrients
management_practices.evidence: If inorganic fertilizer were used to restore the mined nutrients, it would cost an equivalent of a fifth of the farm income.

management_practices.application_rate: elevated levels of N, K, and P-containing fertilizers as well as other macro and micronutrients
management_practices.effect: increase crop yields, have prevented soil nutrient depletion, and, in some cases, have even built-up soil fertility
management_practices.evidence: To increase crop yields, elevated levels of nitrogen (N), potassium (K), and phosphorus(P)-containingfertilizersaswellasothermacroandmicronutrients have been applied in croplands since the end of World War II, have prevented soil nutrient depletion, and, in some cases, have even built-up soil fertility

management_practices.application_rate: balanced fertilization (both from inorganic and organic sources)
management_practices.effect: satisfactory crop growth and production while decreasing production costs
management_practices.evidence: Crop nutrition and balanced fertilization (both from inorganic and organic sources) are considered among the primary actions towards satisfactory crop growth and production while decreasing production costs.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Umbrisol (Luyinjayinja)
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium were limiting nutrients for bean production in Umbrisol (Luyinjayinja)

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Cambisol (‘Limyufumyufu)
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: in Cambisol (‘Limyufumyufu), common bean production was most limited by soil acidity.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Phaeozem
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: the Phaeozem registering greater leaf number and growth

climate_requirements.evidence: However, rainfall is highly variable in most parts of the country both in terms of length of the rainy season and amount of rainfall (DWD, 1995).

management_practices.effect: potential eutrophication of aquifers due to excess Nitrogen application
management_practices.evidence: Level of fertilizer use is another factor revealed under this study, where 10% of the farmers where using fertilizer but the problem here was that most of the farmers do not know which fertilizer combinations to use, which poses a risk for application of excess fertilizers a case of Nitrogen where most of the farmers in Bududa and Mbale were applying NPK + Urea as a combination. This may lead to eutrophication of aquifers.

management_practices.effect: negative environmental and soil/crop health impacts
management_practices.evidence: Another factor was utilization of animal droppings by farmers; where results revealed that most of the animal droppings are just applied directly in the field without transforming it into manure form or disposed-off as waste. This was majorly observed in Mbale district. This also has environmental implications and on soil and crop health.

management_practices.effect: environmental degradation and soil health degradation
management_practices.evidence: Results also showed that land size significantly influenced nutrient management practices, a case of Namutumba where a larger land size led to production of a lot of biomass that attracted burning of residuals by farmers on-farm as their means of disposal. This eventually causes risks for environmental degradation and soil health.

soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Liddugavu(black)soilcorrespondedtoPhaeozem(WRB)andUdolls(USSoilTaxonomy)andisconsistentlyviewedasthemostproductivesoilduetofasterweedgrowth,diversityofcropsitsupports anditsstablelandscapelocation.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Improved soil fertility
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Improved soil fertility can improve yields by over 50%

management_practices.effect: improves yields
management_practices.evidence: mulching and use of surface water management practices improve yields by single digit percentages

management_practices.effect: improves yields
management_practices.evidence: mulching and use of surface water management practices improve yields by single digit percentages

management_practices.effect: increased water stress in dry climates, increased yields need to go hand in hand with water management strategies
management_practices.evidence: The use of fertilizer application needs to go hand in hand with other water management strategies since more yields as a result of the improved soil fertility leads to increased water stress, especially for the dry climates.

climate_requirements.evidence: Maize, the most widely grown crop was used for the study.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Soil acidity
soil_crop_relationships.threshold: At least 40% of arable land affected
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Soil acidity is one of the most prevalent problems in production of food and fiber because at least 40%, and by some estimates as much as 70%, of the world’s arable land is affected.

management_practices.effect: Increase soil pH, ameliorate acidic soils
management_practices.evidence: Although liming can effectively increase soil pH and thus ameliorate acidic soils, the large amounts required and the absence of lime pits positioned close to the paddocks where lime is needed make soil liming an expensive option in many situations.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Soil nitrogen supplying potential
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: The major limiting nutrient for lowland rice production is nitrogen and the soil nitrogen supplying potential can support yield target of 2.8 t ha-1.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Indigenous Phosphorus supply
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Whereas, the indigenous Phosphorus and Potassium supply can support yield target of up to 9 t ha-1 and therefore, not limiting at achievable yield targets of 6 tha-1.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Indigenous Potassium supply
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Whereas, the indigenous Phosphorus and Potassium supply can support yield target of up to 9 t ha-1 and therefore, not limiting at achievable yield targets of 6 tha-1.

management_practices.effect: Target yield of 5 t ha-1
management_practices.evidence: 65 kg N ha-1 is the optimum rate for lowland rice and this corresponds to a target yield of 5 t ha-1.

management_practices.effect: Grain yield increased from 1.3 Mg ha-1 to 3.7 Mg ha-1
management_practices.evidence: Mean grain yield, with hulls, was 1.3 and 3.7 Mg ha-1 with 0 and 100 kg ha-1 N applied, respectively.

management_practices.effect: increased grain yield but less than N application
management_practices.evidence: Grain yield response to applied P when compared with N was less

management_practices.effect: No increase in grain yield
management_practices.evidence: mean yield was not increased with K application

recommendations.economic_optimum: 54 to 92 kg ha-1 N and 17 to 30 kg ha-1 P
recommendations.evidence: Depending on fertilizer cost relative to grain price (CP), mean EOR ranged from 54 to 92 kg ha-1 N and 17 to 30 kg ha-1 P.

soil_crop_relationships.threshold: No major significant differences between cultivars
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: The results showed no major significant nutrient use efficiencies between cultivars with FHIA 17 having the highest nutrient use efficiency. There were a few positive correlations between soil and plant nutrients.

soil_crop_relationships.evidence: However, during the wet 2017/18 season, the combination of RT +mulching at planting +high fertilizer rate yielded the best (3.5 t ha-1).

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Sandy Soil
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: On the sandy soil, the combination of CT +mulching (at both stages) +high fertilizer rate achieved the highest maize grain yield of 2.6 and 2.8 t ha-1 during the 2015/16 and 2016/17, respectively.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Clayey Soil
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: On clayey soil, CT +mulching (at both stages) +high fertilizer rate gave the highest yields of 2.4, 2.9 and 3.4 t ha-1 in 2015/16, 2016/17 and 2017/18, respectively.

management_practices.timing: At planting or tasseling or at both stages
management_practices.effect: Reduced ASI by 4 days
management_practices.evidence: anthesis-silking interval (ASI) was shorter by 4 days following mulching at tasseling.

management_practices.application_rate: Low (35 kg N ha-1, 14 kg P ha-1 and 3 t ha-1 of manure) and high (90 kg N ha-1, 26 kg P ha-1 and 7 t ha-1 of manure)
management_practices.effect: Increased yield, especially when combined with tillage and mulching
management_practices.evidence: Overall, the combination CT +mulching (at both stages) +high fertilizer rate increased maize yield by over 200 % and 300 % compared to the non-mulched treatments on sandy and clay soil, respectively, particularly during seasons with high incidences of intra-seasonal dry spells.

climate_requirements.rainfall_requirement: Rainfed conditions, susceptible to dry spells
climate_requirements.evidence: The high frequency of prolonged intra-season dry spells since the turn of the 21st century continues to heighten risk of crop failure in rainfed cropping systems of Southern Africa including Zimbabwe.

management_practices.evidence: The studies have revealed that the Agrinex NPK soil testing tablets should be applied to a soil sample, and then the soil colour can be sensed using an LDR colour sensor to predict the phosphorus (P), nitrogen (N), and potassium (K) values.

climate_requirements.evidence: Grows better in place with annual rainfall of 500-700 mm.

climate_requirements.growing_season: 90-180 days (temperate, subtropical and tropical lowland cultivars), 120-300 days (tropical highland types)
climate_requirements.evidence: Maize (temperate, subtropical and tropical lowland cultivars for grain and silage maize with growth cycles of 90 to 180 days, tropical highland types of 120 up to 300 days) is an annual crop belonging to the group of crops with a C4 photosynthesis pathway (C4 II), which is characterized with optimum photosynthesis and growth at temperatures between 20°C and 30°C. Temperatures above 30°C lead to lower photosynthesis and temperatures between 35°C and 40°C may cause heat stress and eventually plant damage, especially during the reproductive phase. Annual rainfall requirements for maize may vary from 500 mm up to 2,000 mm depending on cultivar and environment.
Minimum temperature for germination is 10°C and ideally above 15°C.

management_practices.effect: Increased soil moisture storage (1-12%) compared to control (bare soil)
management_practices.evidence: Results showed that CSA practices significantly increased (P < 0.05) total soil water storage (1–12%) than the control treatment.

water_use_efficiency.evidence: It was also noted that; the use of M, PPB, and HM increased the water use efficiency by 9–68% and 8–66% of grain yield compared to the control in the three growing seasons.
It was also noted that; the use of M, PPB, and HM increased the water use efficiency by 9–68% and 8–66% of grain yield compared to the control in the three growing seasons.
It was also noted that; the use of M, PPB, and HM increased the water use efficiency by 9–68% and 8–66% of grain yield compared to the control in the three growing seasons.

climate_requirements.evidence: Wheat belongs to the C3 crop group (C3 I) which is characterized with optimum photosynthesis and growth at temperatures between 15⁰C and 20⁰C. Temperatures above 20⁰C lead to lower photosynthesis, and temperatures above 30⁰C cause growth cycle curtailment and severe heat stress, both leading to lower yields. The length of the total growing period of spring wheat ranges from 100 to 130 days while winter wheat needs about 180 to 250 days to mature.

climate_requirements.growing_season: Requires a cold period (vernalization). Strong resistance to frost down to -20°C
climate_requirements.evidence: Winter wheat requires a cold period or chilling (vernalization) during early growth for normal heading under long days. Winter wheat in its early stages of development exhibits a strong resistance to frost, down to - 20°C. For winter and spring wheat minimum daily temperature for measurable growth is about 5°C.

Spring wheat does not require chilling for heading and it is day-neutral. However, it is also sensitive to frost. For winter and spring wheat minimum daily temperature for measurable growth is about 5°C.

climate_requirements.evidence: The climate is changing across Uganda with mean annual temperature increasing by 1.3◦Celsius since 1960 and decreasing annual and summer rainfall (McSweeney et al., 2010; Williams et al., 2012). Expected further increases in temperature and in the frequency of extreme rainfall events will affect crop production and increase the risk of food insecurity and poverty (McSweeney et al., 2010; Ongoma et al., 2018).
